title: The Vandals start their westward trek from Dacia and Hungary.

title: King Gwanggaeto the Great of Goguryeo (Korea) defeats the forces of Later Yan, seizing some of their border fortresses.

subtitle: Today in history

title: Porphyry of Gaza orders the destruction of pagan temples in Gaza.

subtitle: Today in history

title: The dome in Ravenna is built by the entire population of the city.
subtitle: Today in history

subtitle: Today in history

title: Gwanggaeto the Great of Goguryeo (Korea) attacks Liaodong and takes the entire Liaodong Peninsula.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Chinese Buddhist monk Huiyuan, who founded the Pure Land Buddhism sect and the monastery on Mount Lushan, writes the book ''On Why Monks Do Not Bow Down Before Kings'' in this year. subtitle: Today in history

title: Eudoxia exiles John Chrysostom, bishop of Constantinople, for criticizing her sumptuous lifestyle. He is banished to the Caucasus in Armenia. Pope Innocent I at Rome orders a synod to reinstate the bishop, but his envoys are imprisoned. Atticus becomes the new bishop of Constantinople.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Radagaisus is executed, 12,000 quotbarbariansquot are incorporated into the Roman army or sold as slaves.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Autumn ampampndash The remaining Roman legions in Britain decided to mutiny. The usurper Marcus is proclaimed emperor.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Vandals led by Godigisel are intercepted and defeated by the Franks under Marcomir. Godigisel is killed in battle and succeeded by his son Gunderic.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Vandals, Alans and Suebians cross the Rhine at Mogontiacum (modern Mainz), beginning an invasion of Gaul (traditional date, this may have occurred in 405).

subtitle: Today in history

title: Hanzei succeeds his brother Richu, and becomes the 18th emperor of Japan.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Cultivation of rye, oats, hops, and spelt (a wheat used for livestock feed) is introduced into Europe by the invading Vandals, Alans, and Scirii, who also introduce a heavy wheeled plow to be used for farming.

title: Stained glass is used for the first time in churches in Rome.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Emperor Arcadius dies in his palace at Constantinople after a weak 13-year reign. He is succeeded by his 7-year-old son, Theodosius II, who rules under the domination of his devout Christian sister Pulcheria and Anthemius, who acts as regent.

title: Summer ampampndash Emperor Honorius marries Thermantia, second daughter of Stilicho, his famous general (''magister militum'').
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Roman usurper Constantine III established his headquarters at Arles (Southern Gaul) and elevates his eldest son, Constans, to the rank of ''Caesar''. subtitle: Today in history

title: Stilicho is accused of treason against Honorius and is decapitated at Ravenna. His Hun bodyguard is killed, mass murders of Vandal soldiers followed.The End of Empire. Christopher Kelly, 2009. ISBN 978-0-393-33849-2
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Hexamilion wall is constructed. Fortifications are built across the Isthmus of Corinth guarding the only land route into the Peloponnese peninsula from Greece.
subtitle: Today in history

title: September ampampndash Alaric I, king of the Visigoths, crosses the Julian Alps with an army of 30,000 men and marches into the Roman heartland. He lays siege to Rome and Gothic auxiliaries desert to join Alaric's forces. After much bargaining, the Senate agrees to pay him a ransom of 5,000 pounds of gold, 30,000 pounds of silver, 4,000 silken tunics, and 3,000 hides dyed scarlet.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Huns under Uldin cross the lower Danube and attack the Eastern Roman Empire, setting fire to frontier forts and taking control of the Castra Martis (modern Bulgaria). The Romans negotiate for peace, but Uldin demands an exorbitant gold tribute in return for his withdrawal. This demand is rejected and Anthemius forced the Huns back across the Danube.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Attila, age 12, is sent as child hostage to the court at Rome and in return, the Romans sent Flavius Aetius to the Huns.
subtitle: Today in history

subtitle: Today in history

subtitle: Today in history

subtitle: Today in history

title: The Visigothic king Alaric I lays siege to Rome a second time, bringing the inhabitants close to starvation. subtitle: Today in history

title: Honorius agrees that sons of prominent families at court in Ravenna be sent beyond the Danube as hostages in return, later he calls up ten thousand Hun mercenaries.ampampThe End of Empire (p. 56). Christopher Kelly, 2009. ISBN 978-0-393-33849-2ampamp
subtitle: Today in history

title: Famine strikes Hispania, Gaul and the Italian Peninsula.

title: Ming Yuan Di, age 17, succeeds Dao Wu di as ruler of the Chinese Northern Wei (see Northern dynasties).
subtitle: Today in history

title: Galla Placidia, daughter of Theodosius I, is captured by the Visigoths and becomes an  hostage during their move from the Italian Peninsula to Gaul.

title: June ampampndash Attila approaches ''Aurelianum'' (modern Orléans) and the city's inhabitants close the gates forcing him to lay siege. subtitle: Today in history

title: Battle of Vartanantz: King Yazdegerd II defeats the  Armenian army (66,000 men) under their rebel leader Vartan Mamikonian on the Avarayr Plain (Armenia). The anniversary is a national and religious holiday.

title: Yazdegerd II issues an decree to abolishes the Shabbat and orders the execution of Jewish leaders, including the Exilarch.

title: Thorismund succeeds his father Theodoric I as king of the Visigoths. He is crowned in the capital at Toulouse and extends the Visigothic Kingdom in Hispania.

subtitle: Today in history

title: Emperor Valentinian III stabs his commander-in-chief Flavius Aetius to death during a meeting of the imperial council at Ravenna. He has accused Aetius of plotting against him to seize power. title: : Romulus Augustus, Roman usurper of the Western Roman Empire, is deposed by Odoacer at Ravenna. Odoacer spares the boy's life and gives him a pension of 6,000 ''solidii'' but exiles him to the ''quotCastellum Lucullanumquot'' (Castel dell'Ovo), on the island of ''Megaride'', in the Gulf of Naples. His father Orestes is arrested a week earlier near Piacenza and swiftly executed. This event would late be romanticized in Western literature and history as the Fall of Rome and is traditionally used by historians to mark the beginning of the European Middle Ages.

subtitle: Today in history

title: The Nvarsak Treaty is concluded between the Persians and Armenians.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Pope Felix III excommunicates Acacius of Constantinople and Peter III of Alexandria, for their role in having Zeno issue his Edict of Union (''Henotikon'') 2 years ago. He considers the edict to be heretical and the schism between the Church of Rome and the Church of Constantinople widens. The ''Acacian Schism'' will not be resolved until 519.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Visigoth king Euric dies and is succeeded by his son Alaric II. Euric has built a rampart to protect the city of Carcassonne southeast of Toulouse on a bend of the Aude River.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Battle of Isonzo: Theodoric defeats the overwhelming forces of Odoacer at Soča (near Aquileia), forcing his way into Italy.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Battle of Verona: Odoacer is defeated again by Theodoric for a second time. He retreats to the impregnable capital of Ravenna.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Ostrogoths capture the cities Pavia and Milan. The majority of Odoacer's army, including his ''magister militum'' Tufa, surrenders to Theodoric.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The first Temple of Confucius is constructed in Northern China (outside the ancestral temple at Qufu).
subtitle: Today in history

title: Battle of Adda: Theodoric and his ally Alaric II defeat the forces of Odoacer on the Adda River, near Milan.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Theodoric and his Ostrogoths lay siege to Ravenna. The cities, Cesena and Rimini, remain their allegiance to Odoacer.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Empress Feng of the Chinese Northern Wei Dynasty dies. She is buried with magnificent honors, in the Wenming Tomb.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Corn rises to a terrible famine price and before the end of the siege of Ravenna the inhabitants feed on the hides of animals, many of them perish of hunger.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Euphemius becomes patriarch of Constantinople.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Emperor Zeno, age 66, dies of dysentery after a 17-year reign. He has no sons to succeed him and the Albanian-born Anastasius, palace official (''silentiarius'') and  favoured friend of empress Ariadne, is elevated to the throne.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Anastasius I marries Ariadne shortly after his accession. His reign is disturbed by religious distractions and a civil war started by Longinus, brother of late emperor Zeno.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Anti-Isaurian riots break out in the Hippodrome at Constantinople. Longinus and several other Isaurians, including general Longinus of Cardala are exiled to Thebaid (Egypt).
subtitle: Today in history

title: Aelle of Sussex besieges and conquers the fortified town Anderitum in southern Britain. He massacres the population, apparently sub-Roman Brythons (this according to the ''Anglo-Saxon Chronicle'').
subtitle: Today in history

title: Odoacer makes a night assault with his Heruli guardsmen, engaging Theodoric the Great in Ad Pinetam. Both sides suffer heavy losses, but in the end Theodoric repulses the attack, forcing Odoacer back into Ravenna.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Lupicinus becomes bishop of Lyon. He is the founder of the abbeys of Saint Claude (Jura Mountains).
subtitle: Today in history

title: Pope Felix III dies after a 9-year reign in which he has excommunicated Acasius of Constantinople. This dividing the Western Church and Eastern Church (''Acacian Schism''). He is succeeded by Gelasius I as the 49th pope.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Odoacer surrenders Ravenna after a 3-year siege and agrees to a mediated peace with Theodoric the Great. He steadily consolidates his rule and provides security for the local population. His achievement is to manage the transformation of Italy from being the center of a fractured Roman Empire to a successful and independent Ostrogothic Kingdom.The End of Empire (p. 275). Christopher Kelly, 2009. ISBN 978-0-393-33849-2
subtitle: Today in history

title: Onoulphus, brother of Odoacer, is killed during the siege of Ravenna by archers while seeking refuge in a church.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Odoacer is invited to a banquet organised in order to celebrate the peace treaty. During the festivities, Odoacer is killed by Theodoric the Great. His body is skillfully sliced in half in full view of his guests. A massacre of Odoacer's soldiers and supporters follows.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Theodoric the Great allies with the Franks and marries Audofleda, sister of Clovis I. He also marries his own female relatives to princes or kings of the Burgundians, Vandals and Visigoths. Establishing a political alliance with the Germanic kingdoms in the West.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Clovis I marries the Burgundian princess Clotilde, age 18, she is brought up in the Catholic faith and is the daughter of king Chilperic II. Her father is murdered in the same year by his brother Gundobad.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Emperor Xiao Wen Di starts adopting a sinicization policy as well as various reforms. He marries Feng Qing, she becomes empress of the Northern Wei Dynasty.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Pope Gelasius I introduces Valentine's Day, after he has abolished Lupercalia (approximate date).
subtitle: Today in history

title: Gelasius I dies after a 4-year reign and is succeeded by the Rome-born Anastasius II as the 50th pope.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Clovis I is baptized into the  Catholic faith at Rheims, by Saint Remigius. The conversion strengthen the bonds between his Gallo-Roman subjects, led by their Catholic bishops.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Thrasamund succeeds his brother Gunthamund after his death and becomes king of the Vandals. He ends under his rule the persecution of the Catholics.
subtitle: Today in history

title: King Kavadh I of Persia is deposed and exiled to Susiana by his younger brother Djamasp. He is installed by the nobles to the Sassanid throne.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Emperor Xiao Wen Di of Northern Wei starts the Sinicization process by changing his clan name to the Han Chinese surname Yuan.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Pope Anastasius II dies after a 2-year reign in which he has tried to conciliate followers of Acacius, late patriarch of Constantinople, who was excommunicated by Felix III. Anastasius is succeeded by Symmachus as the 51st pope, in the official papal selection in the Lateran Palace (Rome).
subtitle: Today in history

title: Antipope Laurentius is elected quotpopequot in the Basilica di Santa Maria Maggiore.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Flavian II succeeds Palladius as patriarch of Antioch.
subtitle: Today in history

title: During a synod in Rome, which is attended by 72 bishops and all of the Roman clergy, Pope Symmachus makes Antipope Laurentius bishop of the diocese of Nocera in Campania.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Emperor Xiao Wen Di dies of starvation in his capital at Luoyang after a 27-year reign in which he has Sinicized his tribal relatives (Tuoba clan). He also created a Chinese-style government and instituted a land-reform program.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Crown prince Xuan Wu Di, age 16, succeeds his father Xiao Wen Di and becomes emperor of Northern Wei. He appoints his uncle Yuan Xie to provincial governor,  who serves temporarily as regent to form a new government.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The republic of San Marino is established (traditional date).
subtitle: Today in history

title: King Narseh of Persia abdicates, in favor of his son, Hormizd II.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Sima Lun briefly usurps the Jin Dynasty.
subtitle: Today in history

title: In India, a man by the name of Pāņini comes up with the first concept for a spoken and written language. Through a series of some 4000 different rules, this is the first time that a language is described in such a way.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Galerius publishes his edict that begins the persecution of Christians in his portion of the Empire.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Martyrdom of Saint Adrian of Nicomedia.
subtitle: Today in history

title: On a voyage preaching the gospel, Saint Fermin of Pamplona is beheaded in Amiens, France.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Diocletian makes a visit to Rome. The Augusti and the Caesars are united for the first time to celebrate the 20th anniversary of Diocletian's accession.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Triumphal Arch of Maximian is erected in Salonica.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Sassanid Shah Hormizd II succeeds Narseh.
subtitle: Today in history

title: In Mexico the civilization of Teotihuacan flourishes.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Pope Marcellinus dies at Rome after an 8-year reign. The papal throne will remain vacant until 308.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Emperor Diocletian abdicates at age 60 and retires to his palace at Salona (modern Split) on the Adriatic coast after a reign of nearly 21 years in which the last vestiges of republican government have disappeared.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Maximian retires from office and leaves for Campania (southern Italy) to live a life of ease in his luxury villas.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Constantius Chlorus and Galerius are declared Augusti Flavius Valerius Severus and Maximinus II Daia are appointed Caesars.
subtitle: Today in history

title: In the Western Empire, the capital is moved from Rome to Milan. Constantius Chlorus requests leave for his son Constantine I who remains at Galerius's court in Nicomedia, as a virtual hostage.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Summer ampampndash Constantine I joins his father in Gaul, from Bononia (Boulogne) they cross the Channel to Britain and make their way to Eboracum (York), capital of Britannia Secunda and home to a large military base in order to deal with a rebellion by the Picts.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Maximinus II (305–313) persecutes the Christians of Egypt, many of whom take refuge in the desert. In time, this refuge leads to the monastic life. In these monasteries Coptic writing develops, supporting the propagation of Christian texts.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Patron of Pozzuoli, Saint Proculus, and patron of Naples, Saint Januarius are thrown to wild beasts in Pozzuoli's Flavian Amphitheater, then beheaded at Solfatara.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Daysan River floods Edessa.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Landowners dominate the Roman Empire and enjoy the title of senator, which exempts them from the crushing taxes imposed on the rest of the population. The Senate has lost all its power and the landowners almost never attend Senate sessions. Members of municipal senates (''curiales'' or ''decuriones'') are charged with the responsibility of collecting taxes and paying arrears smaller landowners are held responsible for providing recruits for the Roman army and with keeping wastelands under cultivation.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Catherine makes public confession of Christian gospel at a sacrificial feast ordered by Maximinus II at Alexandria. A virgin of royal descent, she is tortured on a spiked wheel (later called ampquotCatherine Wheelampquot) and beheaded her remains are spirited to Mount Sinai.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Council of Illiberis decrees that priests must be celibate. Additionally, it condemns visiting the homes of Jews and prohibits Christian women from marrying Jews, unless they have converted.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Constantius Chlorus dies outside Eboracum (modern York). Constantine I, age 26, is declared Augustus (emperor) by his troops and awaits recognition by Emperor Galerius.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Galerius grants Constantine I the title Caesar and elevates Severus II to co-emperor of the Western Roman Empire.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Maxentius, son of the former Western Emperor Maximian, joins a revolt by the Praetorian Guard in Rome, and is proclaimed Emperor.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Southern Italy bitter over the subjection to taxation, supports Maxentius, as does Africa, Corsica, Sardinia and Sicily.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Galerius sends Severus II to suppress the rebellion in Rome. The soldiers desert him and Severus flees to Ravenna.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Baths of Diocletian are dedicated, the ''thermae'' become the largest imperial baths in Rome.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Franks cross the Rhine, but are repulsed by Constantine I.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Santa Maria Maior de Lisboa is built in Lisbon.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The War of the Eight Princes ends in China.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Basilica of Maxentius and Constantine (Basilica Nova), Rome, is started to be built.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Council of Elvira declares that killing through a spell is a sin and the work of the devil.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Saint Metrophanes becomes bishop of Byzantium.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Christianity is established in Britain. British bishops participate in the councils of Arles (314), Nicaea (325) and Arminum (349).
subtitle: Today in history

title: Emperor Jin Huidi dies after a 16-year reign in which eight dukes of the imperial family have conducted a civil war (War of the Eight Princes) against each other in a struggle for power. Jin Huaidi, age 23, succeeds his father and  becomes third emperor of the Jin Dynasty.
subtitle: Today in history

title: After divorcing his wife Minervina, Constantine the Great marries Fausta Flavia Maxima, the daughter of the retired co-emperor Maximian.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Constantine I established his capital in Augusta Treverorum (Trier). He begins a major expansion of the city, strengthening the walls with fortified gates, building a palace complex and the Imperial Baths.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Severus II is captured and imprisoned at Tres Tabernae. After Emperor Galerius unsuccessfully invades Italy to suppress Maxentius, he is executed (or forced to commit suicide).
subtitle: Today in history

title: r June 26 ampndash Pope Marcellus I succeeds Pope Marcellinus as the 30th pope.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Congress of Carnuntum: Attempting to keep peace within the Roman Empire, the leaders of the Tetrarchy declare Maxentius a public enemy and Licinius is proclaimed Augustus, while rival contender Constantine I is declared Caesar of Britain and Gaul.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Under Constantine I, the Romans defeat the Germans along the Rhine frontier.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Domitius Alexander is acclaimed emperor (against Maxentius) in Carthage, the African provinces come under his rule. This is a dangerous situation, because Rome depends on the grain supply.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Basilica of Maxentius is constructed, the largest building in the Roman Forum.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Kingdom of Xiongnu established in northern China.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Pope Eusebius succeeds Pope Marcellus I as the 31st pope.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Emperor Galerius declares on his deathbed religious freedom and issues his Edict of Toleration, ending persecution of Christians in the Eastern part of the Roman Empire. He dies, age 51, from a gruesome disease, possibly bowel cancer or Fournier gangrene.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Maximinus II divides the Eastern Empire between co-emperor Licinius, and mobilished his army for a campaign in Asia Minor. He recommences the persecution of Christians.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Maxentius, Roman usurper, reconquers the African provinces from Domitius Alexander.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Maxentius builds the Circus of Maxentius near the Via Appia. The circus is 513 meters long and 91 meters wide, and offers an accommodation to some 10,000 people.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Pope Miltiades succeeds Pope Eusebius as the 32nd pope.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Donatist schism occurs in the African church.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Diocletianus dies at his palace in Split (Croatia). Possible he commits suicide.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Jin Huaidi, emperor of the Jin Dynasty, is captured at Luoyang. The capital city is pillaged by Liu Cong, ruler of the Xiongnu state (Huns), the invaders slaughter 30.000 citizens.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Battle of Milvian Bridge: Constantine I defeats usurper Maxentius at the Milvian Bridge and becomes the only Roman Emperor in the West. During the battle, he reportedly has a vision of a cross (''labarum'') with the phrase ''quotin hoc signo vincesquot'' (quotIn this sign you shall conquerquot).
subtitle: Today in history

title: Constantine I enters Rome, he stages a grand ''adventus'' in the city, and is met with popular jubilation. Maxentius' body is fished out of the Tiber and decapitated.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Constantine I forged co-emperor Licinius to a alliance, and offers him his halfsister Constantia in marriage. The Praetorian Guard and Imperial Horse Guard (''equites singulares Augusti'') are disbanded.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Construction begins on the Arch of Constantine in Rome.
subtitle: Today in history

title: c. 312ampampndash315 ampampndash Constantine I Addresses the People in the Roman Forum, sculptural relief on the Arch of Constantine, Rome, is made.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Constantine I adopt the words ''ampquotin hoc signo vincesampquot'' as a motto and have the letters X and P (the first letters of the Greek word Christ) emblazoned on the shields of his Roman legions.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Council of Carthage supports Donatism, which espouses a rigorous application and interpretation of the sacraments. These doctrines will be condemned by the Council of Arles.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Constantine I promotes a policy of state sponsorship of Christianity, perhaps even becoming a Christian himself (see Constantine I and Christianity).
subtitle: Today in history

title: Edict of Milan: Constantine the Great and co-emperor Licinius met at a conference in Mediolanum (modern Milan). They proclaimed a policy of religious freedom for all, ending the persecution of Christians in the Roman Empire.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Emperor Maximinus II crosses with an army (70.000 men) the Bosphorus, and lays siege to Heraclea (Turkey). He captures the city after eight days.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Emperor Jin Huidi is executed by Liu Cong, ruler of the Xiongnu state (Han Zhao). At the imperial new year he and a number of former Jin officials are poisoned.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Crown prince Jin Mindi, age 13, succeeds in Chang'an his uncle Jin Huidi and becomes the new emperor of the Jin Dynasty.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Nintoku, the fourth son of Ōjin, becomes the 16th emperor of Japan.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Basilica of Maxentius and Constantine (Basilica Nova), Rome, is finished.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Constantine I and Licinius accept Christianity, they agree on a policy of religious toleration. In their Edict they return property confiscated from Christians, and end 10 years of persecution.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Battle of Tzirallum: Licinius defeats his rival Maximinus II and becomes Emperor of the Eastern Roman Empire. Maximinus flees to Nicomedia and commits suicide.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Lateran Synod: Donatism is declared a heresy.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Arius preaches of the human nature of Jesus.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Pope Miltiades' reign ends.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Pope Sylvester I succeeds Pope Miltiades as the 33rd pope.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Council of Arles: Confirms the pronouncement of Donatism as a schism, and passes other canons.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Synod of Ancyra: Consulting a magician is declared a sin earning five years of penance.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Alexander becomes Bishop of Byzantium.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Battle of Cibalae: Constantine the Great defeats his rival Licinius near the town of ''Colonia Aurelia Cibalae'' (modern Vinkovci, Croatia). Licinius is forced to flee to Sirmium, and loses all of the Balkans except for Thrace. Peace negotiations are initiated between the two ''Augusti'', but they are unsuccessful.
subtitle: Today in history

title: A large Pictish raid southwards is attempted.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Arch of Constantine is completed near the Colosseum at Rome to commemorate Constantine's victory over Maxentius at the Milvian Bridge. As part of the ceremony Constantine is expected to make a sacrifice to Rome's traditional gods, but he refuses to do so.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Constantine I dedicated the Basilica of Maxentius and installs a large statue of himself inside it.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Crucifixion is abolished as punishment in the Roman Empire.
subtitle: Today in history

title: A program of assistance to the poor is established in the Roman Empire.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Immense baths are constructed in ''Augusta Treverorum'' (modern Trier).
subtitle: Today in history

title: Eusebius becomes bishop of Caesarea (approximate date).
subtitle: Today in history

title: The lamb becomes the symbol of Jesus in Christian art.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Emperor Constantine the Great and co-emperor Licinius elevate their sons Crispus, Constantine II (being still an baby) and Licinius II to ''Caesars''. After this arrangement Constantine rules the dioceses Pannonia and Macedonia, and established his residence at Sirmium, from where he prepares a campaign against the Goths and Sarmatians.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Licinius recognise Constanstine I as senior emperor and executes Valerius Valens.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Sixteen Kingdoms:  Jin Yuandi flees with remnants of the Jin court and noble families to the south. He succeeds Jin Mindi as first emperor of the Eastern Jin Dynasty, and decides to make Jiankang (modern Nanjing) his new capital.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The earliest historically verified reference to tea is recorded, although the Chinese have been drinking the beverage for centuries.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Pappus of Alexandria, Greek philosopher, observes an eclipse of the sun and writes a commentary on ''The Great Astronomer'' (''Almagest'').
subtitle: Today in history

title: s introduced as the birthday of Jesus.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Edict of Constantine I: The ''dies Solis Invicti'' (Sunday) is proclaimed as the day of rest, trade is forbidden and agriculture is allowed.<a href=

>http://projectrestore.com/library/biblereadings/br100.htm Project restore.com Jews continue to observe Sabbath on Saturday, and Constantine himself continues to worship the ancient Roman sun god, Apollo, despite his acceptance of Christianity.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Emperor Constantine I expels the Goths from the Danube frontier and repairs Trajan's Bridge. He leads a expedition into the old province Dacia (modern Romania) and makes peace with the barbarians.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Tuoba Heru launched a coup d'état against his cousin Tuoba Yulü and becomes the new Prince of Dai.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Calcidius translates Plato into Latin.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Constantine I assigns convicts to grind Rome's flour in a move to hold back the rising price of food in an empire whose population has shrunk as a result of plague (see  309 AD).
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Roman Catholic church is allowed to hold property.
subtitle: Today in history

title: A synod in Alexandria condemns Arianism.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Battle of Adrianople: Emperor Constantine the Great defeats his rival Licinius near Adrianople, forcing him to retreat to Byzantium. He invades Thrace with a Visgothic force and raids the countryside. This sees Constantine ruling as sole Emperor.
subtitle: Today in history

title: July ampampndash Battle of Hellespont: Crispus, destroys Licinius' naval fleet in the Dardanelles, allowing his father Constantine the ability to cross over the Bosporus into Asian provinces. Byzantium is besieged and Licinius assembled a second military force, under his newly elevated co-emperor Martinian at Lampsacus (modern Lapseki).
subtitle: Today in history

title: Battle of Chrysopolis: Constantine I definitively defeats Licinius at Chrysopolis, and becomes sole Emperor, thus ending the period of the Tetrarchy. Licinius escapes and gathered around 30,000 of his surviving troops at Nicomedia.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Licinius abdicates his position as Emperor. He is pardoned by Constantine I as a result of the supplication of his wife Constantia (who is Constantine's halfsister), and banished to Thessalonica as a private citizen.
subtitle: Today in history

title: St Peter's Church is founded in Rome.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Eustathius becomes bishop of Antioch.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Crown Prince Jin Chengdi, age 4, succeeds his father Jin Mingdi as emperor of the Eastern Jin Dynasty. During his reign he is largely advised by regents, his uncle Yu Liang and high-level officials.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Constantine the Great, from the Basilica of Maxentius and Constantine, Rome, is started to be made. It is now kept at Palazzo dei Conservatori, Rome.
subtitle: Today in history

title: First Council of Nicaea: Constantine I summons an ecumenical council of bishops in Nicaea (Turkey). The Nicene Creed declares that the members of the Trinity (the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit) are equal. The council decided that Easter is celebrated on the first Sunday after the first full moon after the vernal equinox. Arius is exiled to Illyria, his works are confiscated and consigned to the flames.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Church of the Nativity is built in Bethlehem.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Helena of Constantinople discovers the so-called True Cross and the Holy Sepulchre (Jesus's tomb) in Jerusalem. (traditional date)
subtitle: Today in history

title: Helena, mother of Constantine I, tells him that he must atone for executing his son and wife by building churches.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The first church is built on the site of Vatican City, traditional place of Saint Peter's tomb.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Construction begins on the churches of Golgotha.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Christianity is introduced to the republic of Georgia by Saint Nino.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Alexandria's patriarch Bishop Alexander dies and is succeeded by his deacon Athanasius.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Emperor Constantine the Great dedicates Constantinople, or ''Nova Roma'' (modern Istanbul), and moves the capital of the Roman Empire there from Rome. He has spent 4 years building the city on the site of ancient Byzantium having chosen the site for its strategic location (a seaport with easy access to Anatolia and the Danube).
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Goths devastate the city of Tanais in the Don River delta.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Ezana, king of Axum, extends his area of control to the west. He defeats the Nobates, and destroys the kingdom of Meroë.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Frumentius is the first bishop of Ethiopia (approximate date).
subtitle: Today in history

title: Eustathius, Patriarch of Antioch, is banished to Trajanopolis.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Bible is translated into the Gothic language by Wulfila.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Pagan temples are starting to be progressively abandoned, destroyed or left to fall into disrepair, save those that are transformed into Christian churches.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Constantine I announces a free distribution of food to the citizens in Constantinople, similar to the food given out in the city of Rome. The amount is approximately 80,000 rations a day, doled out from 117 distribution points around the city.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Constantine I elevates his youngest son Constans to the rank of ''Caesar'' at Constantinople.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Shi Hong succeeds his father Shi Le as Emperor of the Later Zhao Empire, in the Period of the Sixteen Kingdoms.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Emperor Constantine I consecrated the Church of the Holy Sepulchre in Jerusalem.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Flavius Dalmatius is raised to the rank of Caesar, with control of Thracia and Macedonia.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Hannibalianus, nephew of Constantine I, is made ''Rex Regum'' (ampquotKing of Kings of the Pontic peopleampquot).
subtitle: Today in history

title: Athanasius is banished to Trier, on charge that he prevented the corn fleet from sailing to Constantinople.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Samudragupta succeeds Chandragupta I as king of the Gupta Empire.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Tuoba Hena ousts Tuoba Yihuai as chieftain of the Tuoba Clan.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Emperor Shi Hu moves the capital of the Later Zhao state to Yecheng.
subtitle: Today in history

title: First Synod of Tyre: Constantine I convenes a  gathering of bishops at Tyre to depose and exile Athanasius, the Patriarch of Alexandria.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Constantine I reinstated the Alexandrian priest Arius in a synod at Jerusalem. He is declared a heretic at the Council of Nicaea (see 336 AD).
subtitle: Today in history

title: Pope Sylvester I dies at Rome after a 21-year reign. He is succeeded by Mark as the 34th pope.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Pope Mark succeeds Pope Sylvester I as the 34th pope.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Pope Mark begins to build the basilica of San Marco, the church is devoted to St. Mark.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Arius, Alexandrian priest, collapses in the street at Constantinople (approximate date).
subtitle: Today in history

title: Pope Mark dies at Rome after an 11-month reign. No successor is immediately found.
subtitle: Today in history

title: A 4-month papal vacancy ends. Pope Julius I succeeds Pope Mark as the 35th pope.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Constantine the Great, first Christian Roman Emperor of the Western empire (312–324), and of the Roman Empire (324–337), dies in Achyron, near Nicomedia, at age 65 after he is baptized by Eusebius of Nicomedia.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Constantius II announces the restoration of Athanasius as Patriarch of Alexandria.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Paul I becomes Patriarch of Constantinople.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Constantine II, Constantius II, and Constans I succeed their father Constantine I as co-emperors. The Roman Empire is divided between the three Augusti (see map).
subtitle: Today in history

title: September ampampndash A number of descendants of Constantius Chlorus and officials of the Roman Empire, are executed. Responsible for a purge against the sons of Constantine I.
subtitle: Today in history

title: King Shapur II of Persia begins a war against the Roman Empire. He sends his troops across the Tigris to recover Armenia and Mesopotamia.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Shapur II besieged the Roman fortress of Nisibis (Syria), but is repulsed by the forces under Lucilianus.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The original Hagia Sophia is dedicated in Constantinople.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Emperor Constans I makes himself extremely unpopular, Magnus Magnentius is proclaimed emperor at Autun (Gaul) with support of the army on the Rhine frontier.
subtitle: Today in history

title: January ampampndash Constans I flees to Spain, where he is subsequently assassinated at ''Castrum Helenae''. Magnentius rules the Western Roman Empire and is far more tolerant towards Christians and Pagans.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Vetranio is asked by Constantina, sister of Constantius II, to proclaim himself Caesar. Constantius accept the new emperor and sends him money to raise an army.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Iulius Nepotianus, Roman usurper, proclaims himself quotemperorquot and enters Rome with a group of gladiators.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Nepotianus is defeated and killed by Marcellinus, a trusted general sent by Magnentius. His head is put on a lance and borne around the city.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Vetranio meets Constantius II at Naissus (Serbia) and assembled the troops. He is forced to abdicated his title and Constantius allows him to live as a private citizen on a state pension.
subtitle: Today in history

title: About this time the Huns begin to invade the Sassanid Empire.ampampRoberts,  J: ampquotHistory of the World.ampquot. Penguin, 1994.ampamp
subtitle: Today in history

title: The city of Anbar (Iraq) is founded by king Shapur II.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Wei-Jie war breaks out in North China.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The church of Santa Constanza in Rome is finished.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Emperor Constantius II elevates his 25-year-old cousin Constantius Gallus to Caesar at Sirmium (Pannonia). He arranges a marriage with his sister Constantina and puts him in charge of the Eastern Roman Empire. Constantius marches West with a large army (60,000 men) to fight against Magnus Magnentius.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Jewish revolt against Gallus breaks out. After his arrival at Antioch, the Jews begin a rebellion in Palestine. The Roman garrison in the town of Diocesarea is destroyed.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Battle of Mursa Major: Constantius II defeats the usurper Magnentius along the valley of the Drava. The battle is one of the bloodiest in Roman military history. During the fighting Marcellinus is killed.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Winter ampampndash Magnentius flees to Aquileia in northern Italy and fortifies the mountain passes in the Alps.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Emperor Shi Zhi is killed by Ran Min's forces, an action that sets the stage for Wei's victory in the Wei-Jie war (China).
subtitle: Today in history

title: Fú Jiàn declares himself ampquotHeavenly Princeampquot (''Tian Wang'') during the collapse of Later Zhao, and established Former Qin.
subtitle: Today in history

title: In India, a new process makes possible the extraction of sugar from sugarcane.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Macedonius is restored as Patriarch of Constantinople.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Pope Julius I dies after a 15-year reign in which he has made himself the chief opponent of Arianism. He is succeeded by Pope Liberius as the 36th pope who immediately writes to Constantius II requesting a council at Aquileia to discuss the former Alexandrian patriarch Athanasius, who opposes the Arian belief to which the emperor subscribes.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Arbitio and Lollianus Mavortius begin their term as Roman consuls.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Claudius Silvanus, accused of treason, proclaims himself Roman Emperor. After 28 days, Ursicinus arrives from Rome and has Silvanus murdered.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Emperor Constantius II raises in Mediolanum (Italy), his cousin Julian the Apostate to the rank of ''Caesar''. He takes command of the western provinces and marries Constantius' sister, Helena.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Lentienses, a Germanic tribe, are fined by the Roman commander Arbetio under Constantius II for several incursions  against the Roman Empire.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Franks besiege Cologne for ten months.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Huns of Central Asia begin their great drive westwards with an advance into Scythia (modern Russia). They overcome and absorb the Alans, a nomadic and warlike horse breeding people from the steppes northeast of the Black Sea.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Pope Liberius refuses to sign a condemnation of Athanasius, Patriarch of Alexandria, imposed at Milan by Constantius II. Liberius is exiled to Beroea (Greece) and replaced by Felix II. He becomes an antipope and bishop of Rome.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Emperor Constantius II issues a decree closing all pagan temples in the Roman Empire and ordering the banishment once again of the anti-Arian patriarch of Alexandria, Athanasius. He tries to have him arrested during a vigil service, but Athanasius flees to the Nitrian desert in Upper Egypt.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The veneration of non-Christian images is banned in the Roman Empire.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Siege of Autun: Julian receives a report that Augustodunum (Autun) is under attack by the Alemanni. The city walls are in poor state and in danger of falling.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Battle of Reims: Julian is defeated by the Alemanni at Reims (Gaul).
subtitle: Today in history

title: Battle of Brumath: Roman forces pursued Germanic warbands through the Gallic countryside. Julian wins an open battle near Brumath (Alsace).
subtitle: Today in history

title: Rhaetia (Switzerland) is invaded by the Alemanni.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Winter ampampndash Siege of Senonae: Julian over-wintered at Senonae (Bourgogne). German federated troops (''foederati'') desert and hostile warbands besieged the town.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Naemul becomes king of the Silla dynasty (Three Kingdoms of Korea).
subtitle: Today in history

title: Anthony the Great dies at his hermitage near the Red Sea in mid-January at age 103 (approximate), having preached against Arianism and tried to codify guidelines for monastic life.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Construction begins on the first basilica of Saint Peter in Rome.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Emperor Constantius II enters Rome for the first time to celebrate his victory over Magnentius. He address the Senate and the Roman people.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Battle of Strasbourg: Julian, ''Caesar'' (deputy emperor) and supreme commander of the Roman army in Gaul, wins an important victory against the Alemanni at Strasbourg (Argentoratum). He drives the barbarians back behind the Rhine.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Julian builds in Gaul a fleet to secure the corn supply from Britain for the garrisons (''castella'') of the Rhine.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Imperial Library of Constantinople is founded.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Ammianus Marcellinus describes the Pantheon as being ampquotrounded like the boundary of the horizon and vaulted with a beautiful loftinessampquot.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Winter ampampndash Constantius II receives ambassadors from the Persian Empire. They demand that Rome restores the lands surrendered by king Narseh.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The reign of Fú Jiān, the emperor of Former Qin, commences in China.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Alans rout the Hun army in Western Asia.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Saran, King of Ulster, is overthrown.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Pope Liberius travels to Sirmium (Pannonia) late in the year and agrees to sign documents that effectively undo the Nicene Creed (which has implicitly disavowed Arianism) and to sever his relationship with the former Alexandrian patriarch Athanasius, who is replaced as bishop of Alexandria by his Arian opponent George of Cappadocia.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Sixteen Kingdoms: Jin Aidi, age 20, succeeds Jin Mudi as emperor of the Eastern Jin Dynasty.
subtitle: Today in history

title: 361ampampndash363 ampampndash Julian the Apostate, coin is issued. It is now kept at the British Museum, London.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Constantinople enforces a strict licensing system for physicians.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Emperor Julian tries to organize a pagan church and substitute it for Christianity. Pope Liberius repudiates the Arian creed and declares that the Council of Arminium had no authority to issue decrees.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Gregory Nazianzus, (Saint Gregory the Theologian), returns to Nazianzus and becomes a priest by his father. Who wants him to assist local Christians.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Emperor Constantius II dies of a fever at Mopsuestia in Cilicia, age 44, on his deathbed he is baptised and declares his cousin Julian the Apostate rightful successor.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Julian becomes sole emperor of the Roman Empire, he rules from Constantinople and tries to restore paganism. Constantius II is buried in the Church of the Holy Apostles.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Ministers and followers of Constantius II are put to trial at the Chalcedon tribunal.
subtitle: Today in history

title: George of Cappadocia is murdered in Alexandria and Athanasius returns to his native city in triumph.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Athanasius returns to Alexandria and convenes a council at which he appeals for unity among Christians who differ in terminology, but emperor Julian orders Athanasius to leave Alexandria. He will remain in exile in Upper Egypt until after Julian's death next year.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Emperor Julian arrives at Antioch with an expeditionary force (60,000 men) and stays there for nine months to launch a campaign against the Persian Empire. He secures the co-operation with Arsaces, king of Armenia, who fights a bloody guerrilla war against the Persians.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Julian builds at Samosata (Commagene) a fleet of 50 warships and over a 1,000 transport boats, for his expedition in Persia against king Shapur II the Great.
subtitle: Today in history

title: An earthquake strikes Nicaea (Turkey).
subtitle: Today in history

title: An earthquake strikes Al-Karak (Jordan).
subtitle: Today in history

title: The temple of Apollo at Daphne, outside Antioch, is destroyed in a mysterious fire.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Emperor Julian departs from Antioch with his army (90,000 men) and heads north towards the Euphrates. On route he creates a diversion and sends a force of 30,000 soldiers under his cousin Procopius to Armenia.
subtitle: Today in history

title: April ampampndash Julian crosses the Euphrates near Hierapolis, using 50 pontoon ships, and moves eastwards to Carrhae. He destroyed Perisapora and overruns Persian forts along the desert frontier (''Limes Arabicus'').
subtitle: Today in history

title: The planet Venus occults the planet Jupiter.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Council of Laodicea, which deals with constricting the conduct of church members, is held.  The major canon approved by this council is Canon 29, which prohibits resting on the Sabbath (Saturday), restricting Christians to honoring the Lord on Sunday.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Battle of Ctesiphon: Julian reaches the vicinity of the strongly fortified capital Ctesiphon. King Shapur II in charge of a large Persian army adopts a scorched earth policy, leaving the Romans desperately short of supplies.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Roman army starts its retreat northward to Corduene (Armenia). Julian marches back up the Tigris and burns his fleet of supply ships. During the withdrawal Julian's forces suffering several attacks from the Persians.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Battle of Samarra: Julian is mortally wounded in a skirmish and dies from a wound received during the fightings near Samarra (Iraq). Jovian, general of the Guard, succeeds him and is proclaimed Emperor by the troops.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Emperor Jovian negotiates a disastrous peace with Persia, surrendering four of the five Roman provinces gained by Caesar Galerius in 298, and the cities Nisibis and Singara (Mesopotamia).
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Huns first appear in Europe and reach the Caspian Sea.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Petra, capital of the Nabataeans, is damaged by an earthquake.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Emperor Jovian dies after a reign of eight months. He is found dead in his tent at Tyana (Asia Minor) en route back to Constantinople in suspicious circumstances.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Valentinian I is proclaimed Emperor by the Roman army. He addresses the soldiers in a speech who threatened to riot.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Valens, brother of Valentinian I, is appointed co-emperor (''Augustus'') in the palace of Hebdomon (Turkey). He begins the first anti-pagan persecutions.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Valentinian I rules from Caledonia (Scotland) to the Rhine frontier the Western Roman Empire and Valens reigns from the Danube to the Persian border the Eastern Roman Empire.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Valentinian I founded the Valentinian Dynasty and settles in Paris. He  establishes a militia to defend the region. His reign ensures the Roman Empire a few years of relative security.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Britain is forced to endure fierce Barbarian raids.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Council of Laodicea decides some disciplinary questions of the Christian church and attempts to establish the Biblical canon, but fails.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Sixteen Kingdoms: Jin Feidi, age 23, succeeds his brother Jin Aidi as emperor of the Eastern Jin Dynasty. He has no actual power, governmental matters are largely in the hands of his granduncle Sima Yu.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Basil of Caesarea becomes presbyter of Caesarea.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Emperor Valens orders the expulsion of the Alexandrian bishop Athanasius from his see, but instead of going into exile Athanasius, now about 67, moves to the outskirts of Alexandria.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Antipope Felix II dies after a 9-year reign, ending the double occupancy of the papacy.
subtitle: Today in history

title: An earthquake and tsunami devastates Crete and Alexandria and affects Italy, Greece, and Palestine.<a href=
>http://earthquake.usgs.gov/learning/today/his_07_21.php Earthquakes site
subtitle: Today in history

title: Procopius revolts and bribes two legions passing by Constantinople. He proclaims himself Emperor, and takes control of Thrace and Bithynia.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Alamanni cross the Rhine and invade Gaul. Emperor Valentinian I moves to Paris to command the army and defend the Gallic cities.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Alamanni cross the frozen Rhine in large numbers, and invade the Gallic provinces. They capture Alsace and a large part of the Swiss Plateau.
subtitle: Today in history

title: AprilampampndashMay ampampndash Emperor Valens defeats the troops of Procopius in the Battle of Thyatira, bringing an end to his revo Serenianus and Marcellus are killed. He flees the battlefield, but is executed by Valens.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Valens builds a pontoon bridge across the Danube and drives the Visigoths farther north, where they will come under pressure from the advancing Huns.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Winter ampampndash Emperor Valentinian I appoints Jovinus, his Master of the Horse (''Magister Equitum''), general of the army. He defeats the Alamanni in three successive battles and push them out of Gaul.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The ''Tabula Peutingeriana'', a map showing Roman possessions and roads, is created about this time.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Athanasius of Alexandria returns from his fifth exile. He spent four months in his ancestral tomb outside Alexandria.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Buddhist monk Lè Zūn has a vision of ampquotgolden rays of light shining down on 1,000 Buddha'sampquot, resulting in the creation of the Mogao Caves.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Pope Liberius dies after a 14-year reign and is succeeded by Damasus I as  37th pope. Romans unhappy with this choice  elect the antipope Ursicinus.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Gratian receives the title of ''Augustus'' under his father, Valentinian I.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Winter ampampndash Valentinian I mobilises a massive army for his campaign against the Alamanni and the Franks. He summons the Italian and Illyrian legions for a spring offensive.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The first Korean envoy arrives in Japan, emissary of the government of Kudara.
subtitle: Today in history

title: First Listing of the New Testament (Bible) by St Athanasius of Alexandria.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Antipope Ursicinus is banished by the ''praefecti'' to Gaul.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Epiphanius of Salamis becomes bishop of Salamis, Cyprus.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Emperor Valens is baptized by Eudoxius of Antioch.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Jin Xiaowudi, age 10, succeeds his father Jin Jianwendi. Empress Chu Suanzi serves as regent, but decisions are made by the high officials Xie An and Wang Tanzhi.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The first diplomatic ties are established between the Korean kingdom of Baekje and the Chinese court of the Jin Dynasty.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The national academy of Chinese learning, called Taehak, is established in the kingdom of Goguryeo (Korea).
subtitle: Today in history

title: Gregory of Nyssa becomes bishop.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Buddhism is adopted as the official religion of Gorguryeo.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Saint Augustine adopts Manichaeism.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Valentinian I bans Manichaean meetings.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Spearthrower Owl ascends to the throne and becomes ruler of Teotihuacan (Mexico).
subtitle: Today in history

title: The people of Milan astonish Ambrosius, governor of Aemilia-Liguria, by acclaiming him bishop. He is the second son of the former praetorian prefect of Gaul, and becomes a creative thinker whose ideas will provide the paradigm for medieval church-state relations.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Emperor Valentinian I concludes an enduring peace with the Alamanni in Germany, then marches into Illyrium to repel an invasion of the Quadi and the Sarmatians on the  Danube frontier. While negotiating with the Quadi, Valentinian, age 54, becomes so enraged that he dies in a fit of apoplexy at Brigetio (Hungary). Extreme cruelty has marked his 11-year reign but has founded schools and provided physicians to serve the poor of Constantinople.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Quadi accept an uneasy peace, Merobaudes (''Magister militum''), gives them land to settle on the Danube.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Gratian, age 16, takes over the government at ''Augusta Treverorum'' (modern Trier), but ministers wishing to retain the loyalty of the Illyrian army and fearing a usurper. They proclaim Valentinian's 4-year-old son Valentinian II co-emperor with his mother, Justina, as regent. Gratian reserves for himself the administration of the Gallic provinces, and hands over Italy, Illyrium, Hispania and Africa to his stepmother, who makes ''Mediolanum'' (Milan) her residence.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Gratian, advised by his chief advisor Ambrosius, begins a systematic presecution of the pagans. He confiscates the fortunes of the temples and adds the money to the Imperial Treasury. He procribes Arianism and Donatism.
subtitle: Today in history

title: In Africa, the dissident Berber prince Firmus is delivered to the Romans by his brother Gildon.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Emperor Chandragupta II becomes ruler of the Gupta Empire (India). He is the son of Samudragupta the Great and attaines his reign by an aggressive expansionist policy.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The earliest extant books – a school textbook and an account book – with bound wooden leaves, are lost at the Dakhla Oasis in western Egypt. The desert sands preserve them for modern archaeologists.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The first two Korean Buddhist temples are built.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Saint Jerome retires to the desert of Chalcis (Syria).
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Maronite Church is founded by Saint Maron in Lebanon.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Talmud of Babylon is written by Rav Ashi. This commentary on the Mishnah contains approximately 2.5 million words on 5.894 pages.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Battle of Adrianople: A large Roman army is defeated by the Visigoths. Valens is killed along with two-thirds of his army.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Goths attack Adrianople they attempt to scale the city walls with ladders but are repelled by the defenders who drop lumps of masonry.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Goths supported by the Huns move on to Constantinople. Their progress is checked by the Saracens, recruited from Arab tribes who control the eastern fringes of the empire.
subtitle: Today in history

title: October ampampndash The Greuthungi, faced with food shortages, split off and move west into Pannonia. Followed by their families they raid villages and farmland.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Gratian recalls his military commander Flavius Theodosius, age 31, son of the executed general Theodosius the Elder and appoints him co-emperor of the Eastern Roman Empire.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Siyah K'ak' begins to replace Mayan kings with relatives of Spearthrower Owl, emperor of Teotihuacan.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Valens completes the aqueduct of Constantinople begun by Constantine I.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Gregory Nazianzus is ordained bishop of Constantinople.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Pope Damasus I is accused of adultery but is exonerated by Gratian.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Emperor Gratian elevates Flavius Theodosius at Sirmium, giving him the title ''Augustus'' with power over all the eastern provinces. Theodosius comes to terms with the Visigoths and settles them in the Balkans as military allies (''foederati'').
subtitle: Today in history

title: Gratian refuses the title of Eastern Emperor.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Gratian renounces the title ''Pontifex Maximus''.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Britain is forced to endure fierce Barbarian raids.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Niall becomes High King of Ireland. ampampAnnals of the Four Masters <a href=
>http://www.ucc.ie/celt/published/T100005A/index.html Annals of the Four Mastersampamp
subtitle: Today in history

title: King Shapur II, ruler of the Persian Empire, age 70, dies after a 69-year reign in which he conquered Armenia and transferred multitudes of people from the western lands to Susiana (Khuzistan). The great town Nishapur in Khorasan (eastern Parthia) is also founded by him. His brother Ardashir II, governor-king of Adiabene, is placed by the nobles on the throne.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Buddhism is declared to be a state religion.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The War of the Feishui is fought in China.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Yax Nuun Ayiin (I) becomes ruler of Tikal.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Gregory Nazianzus becomes Patriarch of Constantinople, and is wounded when he is attacked by a mob of heretics.
subtitle: Today in history

title: John Chrysostom writes a book on the Christian education of children.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Edict of Thessalonica: Theodosius I, with co-emperors Gratian and Valentinian II, declare their wish that all Roman citizens convert to trinitarian Christianity, in accordance with the patriarchs of Rome and Alexandria, implicitly rejecting the Arianism of the patriarch of Constantinople as heretical.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Battle of Thessalonica: The Goths under Fritigern defeat a Roman army in Macedonia. Theodosius I retreats to Thessalonica and leaves Gratian control over the Western Roman Empire.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Rome's enemies the Germans, Sarmatians and Huns are taken into Imperial service as a consequence, barbarian leaders begin to play an increasingly active role in the Roman Empire.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Theodosius I makes his ''adventus'', or formal entry, into Constantinople.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Queen Mavia defeat with her Saracen forces the Roman army in southern Syria.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Invasion of the Vandals: Gratian is forced to cede Upper Pannonia to them.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Rock of Cashel is built in Ireland.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Visigothic chieftain Fritigern dies after ravaging the Balkans his rival Athanaric becomes king of the entire Gothic nation.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The annexation of western provinces by Chandragupta II give him control over commerce with Europe and Egypt.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Easter Island, in the south Pacific Ocean, has been occupied by Neolithic seafarers under Hotu Matua (ampquotsupreme chiefampquot) who about this time begin the fortify the island.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Important works on mathematics and astronomy are written in Sanskrit.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Tyconius writes a commentary on the Bible's Book of Revelation.
subtitle: Today in history

title: A cathedral is built in Trier (Germany).
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Council of Saragossa is held Spanish and Aquitanian bishops condemn the teachings of Priscillianism.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Ambrose introduces popular music into church services.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Emperor Theodosius I commands his general Saturninus to conclude a peace treaty with the Visigoths, allowing them to settle south of the Danube. They are installed as ''foederati'' in Moesia and Thrace with the title of quotAllies of the Roman Peoplequot, in exchange that they furnish a contingent of auxiliary troops to defend the borders.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Emperor Gratian refuse the divine attributes of the Imperial cult and removes the Altar of Victory from the Senate.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Council of Rome establishes Biblical canon in the Catholic Church. Pope Damasus I commissions a revision of the Vetus Latina, eventually resulting in the Vulgate of Jerome.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The same council adopts Trinitarianism as orthodoxy, condemning Apollinarism. Theodosius I orders the death of members of Manichaean monks.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The first sermons declaring the virginity of Mary are given by John Chrysostom.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Arcadius is elevated to Emperor.ref name=quotisbn1-57958-316-4quot
subtitle: Today in history

title: Roman troops in Britain proclaim Magnus Maximus Emperor. He crosses over to the continent and makes Trier his capital.ampref name=ampquotisbn0-85991-625-1ampquotamp
subtitle: Today in history

title: Emperor Gratian, age 24, is assassinated at Lugdunum (modern Lyon), leaving a young widow Laeta. Pannonia and Africa maintain their allegiance to co-emperor Valentinian II, now 12, whose mother, Justina, rules in his name.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Emperor Theodosius I cedes Dacia and Macedonia to Valentinian II. They recognize Magnus Maximus as ''Augustus''.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Theodosius I sends Flavius Stilicho as an envoy to the Persian court of king Shapur III at Ctesiphon to negotiate a peace settlement relating to the partition of Armenia.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Battle of Feishuiampref name=ampquotisbn076560504xampquotamp
subtitle: Today in history

title: King Ardashir II dies after a 4-year reign. He is succeeded by his son Shapur III.ampref name=ampquotisbn0-415-32678-8ampquotamp
subtitle: Today in history

title: First Council of Constantinople (some authorities date this council to 381): Theodosius I calls a general council to affirm and extend the Nicene creed, and denounce Arianism and Apollinarism.  Most trinitarian Christian churches consider this an Ecumenical council.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Eunomius of Cyzicus is banished to Moesia.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Pope Siricius succeeds Damasus I as the 38th pope. He takes the title ''Pontifex Maximus'', after it is relinquished by late emperor Gratian.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Ambrosius refuses the request of empress Justina for a church in Milan, where she can worship according to her Arian belief.
subtitle: Today in history

title: A synod is held in Bordeaux (France).
subtitle: Today in history

title: Magnus Maximus surrenders at Aquileia and is executed. Theodosius I devotes himself to gluttony and voluptuous living. Maximus' son Flavius Victor is executed at Trier by Valentinian's ''magister militum'' Arbogast.
subtitle: Today in history

title: King Shapur III dies after a reign in which he has partitioned Armenia with the Roman Empire. He is succeeded by his son Bahram IV, who becomes the twelfth Sassanid king of Persia.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Emperor Chandragupta II, ruler of the Gupta Empire, begins a war against the Shaka Dynasty in West India.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Paternus becomes bishop of the Episcopal see of Braga (Portugal).
subtitle: Today in history

title: Isaac, age 50, is named ''Catholicos'' (spiritual head) of the Armenian Apostolic Church.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Jerome moves to Palestine, where he spend the rest of his life as a hermit near Bethlehem.
subtitle: Today in history

title: A group of Christians storms the synagogue of the city Callinicum (Syria), at the Euphrates.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Emperor Valentinian II, age 21, is assassinated while advancing into Gaul against the Frankish usurper Arbogast. He is found hanging in his residence at Vienne.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Arbogast nominates Eugenius, Roman teacher of rhetoric, as the next emperor of the Western Roman Empire. He send ambassadors to Theodosius's court, asking for his recognition.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Theodosius I becomes the last emperor who rules the whole Roman Empire. He issues an edict reinforcing the prohibition of prayers or sacrifices at non-Christian temples. He also bans items of spiritual significance that could be used in the home such as incense or spiritual figures.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Emperor Theodosius I proclaims his son Honorius, age 8, co-ruler (''Augustus'') of the Western Roman Empire.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Theodosius I demands the destruction of pagan temples, holy sites, and ancient objects throughout the Roman Empire.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Theodosius I abolishes the Greek Olympic Games, ending a thousand years of festivals, as part of the general Christian policy to establish universal Christian worship in accordance with the doctrines set forth in the Nicene Creed.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Gao Zu succeeds Tai Zu as emperor of the Later Qin Empire.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Chinese astronomers observe the guest star SN 393.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Synod of Hippo: A council at Hippo Regius (Algeria) is hosted by the Christian Church. The bishops approve a canon of Sacred Scripture that correspond to the Roman Catholic Church.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Battle of the Frigidus: Emperor Theodosius I defeats and kills the usurper Eugenius. The forces of Theodosius are bolstered by numerous auxiliaries including 20,000 Visigoth federates under Alaric. The Frankish general Arbogast (''magister militum'') escapes into the Alps and commits suicide.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Late Roman army: The ''Notitia Dignitatum'' shows the development of forces in the Roman Empire. By now 200,000 soldiers guard the borders, and a reserve force of 50,000 is available for deployment. Many non-Roman soldiers are from Germanic tribes: Alamanni, Franks, Goths, Saxons and Vandals.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Winter ampampndash The Huns cross the frozen Danube and destroy the villages build by the Goths. Theodosius I, six hundred miles away in Italy, send no reinforcements to defend the northern frontier.
subtitle: Today in history

title: In Rome the sacred fire stops burning (see Vesta and Vestal Virgins).
subtitle: Today in history

title: The last known hieroglyph is written in Philae, Egypt.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The last ruler of Former Qin, Fu Chong is killed in battle against an army of Western Qin, bringing Former Qin to an end.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Epiphanius of Salamis attacks Origen's followers and urged John II, Bishop of Jerusalem, to condemn his writings.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Council of Bagaï in Africa brings 310 Donatist bishops together.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Emperor Theodosius I, age 48, dies after a disease involving severe edema, at Milan. The Roman Empire is re-divided into an eastern and a western half. The Eastern Roman Empire is centered in Constantinople under Arcadius, son of Theodosius, and the Western Roman Empire in Mediolanum under Honorius, his brother.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Arcadius marries Aelia Eudoxia, daughter of the Frankish general Flavius Bauto. His 3-year-old half-sister, Galla Placidia, is send to Rome where she spent her childhood in the household of Stilicho and his wife Serena.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Alaric, Visigothic leader of the ''foederati'', renounces Roman fealty and is declared king, waging war against both parts of the Roman Empire, and ending a 16-year period of peace.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Goths, led by Alaric I, invade and devastate Thrace and Macedonia, impose a tribute on Athens, and then turn their sights on the West. Arcadius unable to defeat them, gives Alaric control of the Balkans, and grant him the position of ''magister militum'' in Illyricum.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Rufinus, praetorian prefect of the East, is murdered by Gothic mercenaries under Gainas.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Huns begin their first large-scale attack on the Eastern Roman Empire. They invade Armenia, Cappadocia, and enter parts of Syria, threatening Antioch.
subtitle: Today in history

title: King Rudrasimha III, ruler of the Western Satraps (India), is defeated by the Gupta Empire.
subtitle: Today in history

title: An estimated 330,000 acres of farmland lie abandoned in Campania (southern Italy), partly as a consequence of malaria from mosquitoes bred in swampy areas, but mostly because imprudent agriculture has ruined the land.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Possible date that Ambrosius Theodosius Macrobius published his ''Saturnalia''.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Augustine, age 40, becomes bishop of Hippo Regius (modern Algeria). His assignment is the reunification of the Roman Catholic Church in Africa, primarily focusing on the Donatist movement led by Primianus.
subtitle: Today in history

title: First Council of Toledo: Hispanic bishops, including Lampius, condemn Priscillianism.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Sulpicius Severus writes the earliest biography of Martin of Tours, the first known ampquotlife of a saintampquot ever written.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Augustine of Hippo begins his ''ampquotConfessionsampquot'', an autobiograpy that recounts his intellectual and spiritual development.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Ninian, Scottish apostle, establishes a church (''Candida Casa'') at Whithorn, and begins his missionary work among the Picts.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Pope Siricius dies at Rome after a 15-year reign in which he has commanded celibacy for priests, asserted papal authority over the entire Western Church, and threatened to impose sanctions who do not follow his dictates.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Anastasius I succeeds Siricius as the 39th pope. He seeks to reconcile the churches of Rome and Antioch. Anastasius also condemns the doctrine of Origen.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Flavian I is acknowledged as legitimate bishop of Antioch by the Church of Rome.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Emperor Arcadius gives his wife Aelia Eudoxia officially the title of ''Augusta''. She is able to wear the purple paludamentum and is depicted in Roman currency.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Anthemius, praetorian prefect of the East, is sent on an embassy to the Persian capital, Ctesiphon, to congratulate king Yazdegerd I on his accession the year before.ampampThe End of Empire (p. 76). Christopher Kelly, 2009. ISBN 978-0-393-33849-2ampamp
subtitle: Today in history

title: A riot breaks out in Constantinople, the Great Palace is burned to the ground. Gainas, an ambitious Gothic leader, attempts to evacuate his soldiers out of the city but 7,000 armed Goths are trapped and killed by order of Arcadius. After the massacre, Gainas tries to escape across the Hellespont, but his rag-tag ''ad hoc'' fleet is destroyed by Fravitta, a Gothic chieftain in imperial service.
subtitle: Today in history

title: Winter ampampndash Gainas lead the remaining Goths back to their homeland across the Danube. They meet the Huns and are defeated, the Hunnic chieftain Uldin send the head of Gainas to Constantinople where Arcadius received it as a diplomatic gift.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Franks establish themselves in the North of the Netherlands.
subtitle: Today in history

title: The Paeonians (Illyricum) lose their identity (approximate date).
subtitle: Today in history
